top_categories.workout_context: At 130 miles, Dirty Reiver punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
Dirty Reiver’s forest gravel roads (two-track), fist-size embedded rocks demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Racing Dirty Reiver isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Dirty Reiver rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Dirty Reiver when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Dirty Reiver’s forest gravel roads with technical singletrack and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Dirty Reiver — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Dirty Reiver. Make this intensity feel like home.
Dirty Reiver’s 14,100ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at Dirty Reiver — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on forest gravel roads with technical singletrack.
Every session at Dirty Reiver intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
At 130 miles, Dirty Reiver rewards a massive aerobic engine. This volume work builds the fat-oxidation capacity that keeps you moving when glycogen runs low.

race_overlay.heat: April in Kielder, Northumberland, England can bring heat. Complete 3–4 heat exposure sessions in the final 2 weeks before Dirty Reiver. Increase sodium intake 48 hours before race day.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Dirty Reiver’s 130 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Dirty Reiver demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride forest gravel roads with technical singletrack at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: forest gravel roads (two-track), fist-size embedded rocks, rocky mountain-style forest roads. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 130 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, Gravel Specific, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 130 miles of forest gravel roads with technical singletrack in Kielder, Northumberland, England.
